<http://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/7948/when-is-it-ok-to-remove-the-intercept-in-a-linear-regression-model>

attachments.title: When is it ok to remove the intercept in a linear regression model?
attachments.text: I am running linear regression models and wondering what the conditions are for removing the intercept term. In comparing results from two different regressions where one has the intercept and the
attachments.fallback: When is it ok to remove the intercept in a linear regression model?

messages.text: It should not be.  The only reasons for fitting a regression without an intercept are when you are using some encoding of the data that imply including one would introduce linear dependencies or you know mathematically that the intercept must be estimated as zero (you standardized all predictors and the response).

Question 4 on the afternoon_soln.ipynb for Linear Regression (<https://github.com/zipfian/solns/blob/master/linear-regression/afternoon_soln.ipynb>) uses statmodels OLS without first adding a constant. See cell 87. Is this deliberate?

<@U205HNSAV> I’ve updated the master `solns` repo to fix the typos, since the existing solution is broken without these important changes.
One more thing. If using plotly locally, then it needs to initialize in offline mode (`import plotly.offline as po`) and change every `py.iplot` to `po.plot` in part 2
The file also needs `import plotly.graph_objs as go` (module is used in Part 2)

The morning_solution.py file for Linear Regression (<https://github.com/zipfian/solns/blob/master/linear-regression/morning_solution.py>) throws an error because there is mismatch between the module import on line 10 (`from statsmodels.stats.outliers_influence import variance_inflation_factor`) and its use on line 144 (`sm_o.variance_inflation_factor(…`). Removing `smo.` from 144 is an easy fix.

While waiting for an update, here’s the template you should use instead :
```
# Part 3.2.2
def split_csvstring(input_string):
    """Parse a csv-like line and break the values into a list.

    Parameters
    ----------
    input_string (str): a csv-like string to work on

    Returns
    -------
    list : the list of the values

    Example
    -------
    >>> split_csvstring(u'a,b,0.7,"Oct 7, 2016",42,')
    ['a', 'b', '0.7', 'Oct 7, 2016', '42', '']
    “”"
```
(my mistake)
Thanks ! I’ll take care of that.

Spark day problem:
In the given template code (with docstrings) 
<https://github.com/zipfian/spark/blob/master/spark_intro.py>
the first function is defined twice. This will break your code if you only write the first one and don't comment out the second one. 

The second entry is supposed to be the template for `split_csvstring` (part 3.2.2), which is referenced in the assignment ( <https://github.com/zipfian/spark/blob/master/individual.md> ) but doesn't exist.
The DSI AMI described in the assignment (`ami-6534390f`) is no longer available on EC2's Community AMI list.
It's now fixed in the welcome repo as well

In the map-reduce pair, the directions for part 2 say "Now you need to make sure to exclude users who are friends with each other, since we don't care about their mutual friend counts. In your *first reducer* , also yield every pair of users who are friends with a flag to indicate so. You should use a value that isn't 1 (maybe 0) to indicate that two users are friends."    However, the solution shows the flag occurring in the second mapper, where it works much better.  Figuring this out was a source of confusion.

In the NLP solutions markdown (<https://github.com/zipfian/solns-sf1718/blob/master/nlp/individual_soln.md>), instruction number 5 under "bag of words and tfidf" doesn't seem to have a clear solution because the text says:

"Normalize the word count matrix to get the term frequencies. This means dividing each term frequency by the total count of the number of words in that document. This results in each row summing to 1."

while the code below divides it by the l2 norm and not the total count of the number of words in that document - code below:

tf_norm = np.sqrt((word_counts ** 2).sum(axis=1))
tf_norm[tf_norm == 0] = 1
tf = word_counts / tf_norm.reshape(len(my_docs), 1)

can this be clarified so that this part only says one thing?

thanks!

messages.text: That would fix it I think.  Just make it clear that this thing should be taking in a numpy array and not a list

```def only_positive(arr):
    '''
    INPUT: 2 DIMENSIONAL NUMPY ARRAY
    OUTPUT: 2 DIMENSIONAL NUMPY ARRAY
    Return a numpy array containing only the rows from arr where all the values
    are positive.
    E.g.  np.array([[1, -1, 2], [3, 4, 2], [-8, 4, -4]]))  ->  ([[3, 4, 2]])
    '''
    return arr[np.min(arr, 1) > 0]
```
Input is listed as being a 2-d numpy array but the example input that it lists shows passing in a list of lists
<@U256PLJKC> What did you find confusing about the wording of the docstring for `only_positive`?
<@U256PLJKC> If that function requires a 2-dim array, it should really throw an exception if `len(arr.shape) != 2`.

Remember, when posting code snippets, to wrap your code in triple backticks to put your code in a code block for readability purposes!

from __future__ import division


'''
Python class representing a Probability Mass Function
'''


class PMF(object):
    def __init__(self, pmf):
        self.prob_dict = pmf

    def prob(self, event):
        """
        Returns the probability of event happening
        """
        return self.prob_dict[event]

    def set(self, event, likelihood):
        """
        Updates the value of event to be likelihood and then normalizes so that
        the total probability still sums to 1
        """
        rem_prob = 1 - likelihood
        for key, value in self.prob_dict.iteritems():
            self.prob_dict[key] = rem_prob / (len(self.prob_dict) - 1)
        self.prob_dict[event] = likelihood

    def __str__(self):
        """
        Prints a visual representation of the PMF to the terminal
        """
        print self.prob_dict

<@U1UBYJQM6>, to prevent using a for loop in predict and since you're already checking whether a variable is categorical, you can also edit the tree. if you map  your categorical variables to ints in the fit method, store the map, and write a pair of mapping methods to go between ints and strings, then in predict you can predict with ints and return strings. this is certainly more work, but it seems dangerous to mix strings and numpy operations that are not based in recarrays or chararry, given this type of behavior. And it's important to note that the problem is in the code given to the students: <https://github.com/zipfian/random-forest/blob/master/src/DecisionTree.py> (line 204)

Oh shoot, I remember that coming up last time! The problem is in the `predict` method in `DecisionTree.py`.
<https://github.com/zipfian/solns/blob/master/random-forest/DecisionTree.py> (line 209)

`return np.apply_along_axis(self.root.predict_one, axis=1, arr=X)`

results in casting the who numpy array datatype (which, for numpy strings, are fixed-length) as whatever the first entry is (so if "Play" is stored, then later "Don't Play" will get cut off to "Don'"

The solution is to just make a list with a for loop, then cast to an array
```preds = []
for row in X:
    preds.append(self.root.predict_one(row))
return np.array(preds)
```
which you can see here (lines 209 to 212)
<https://github.com/zipfian/solns-sf15/blob/master/4-supervised-learning/random-forest/DecisionTree.py>

thanks <@U1UBYJQM6> and <@U1VN4QD29>! I’ll take a look!
In `recommender-case-study`, the Performotron has a Webhook URL that will post to gAlumni instead of gStudent. <https://github.com/zipfian/recommender-case-study/issues>

A student found a deprecation error in the solutions for Flask day in `build_model.py`, line 12
<https://github.com/zipfian/solns/tree/master/data-products/my_web_app>

Running `build_model.py` gives an error with `pickle.load()` :
`TypeError: _reconstruct: First argument must be a sub-type of ndarray`
which turns out to be a relic of the way old versions of pandas organized its subclasses.

This can be fixed by using 
`data = pd.read_pickle('data/data.pkl')`

instead of 
`data = pickle.load( open('data/data.pkl') )`

or by re-pickling the data.

yeah, that’s probably true. I’ve primarily worked with Hive, which does not optimize
Most RDBMS products will optimize both queries identically which is why I would go for readability. But it does not really matter from the result perspective.
<@U1VD2FR1U>: Moving to the WHERE clause might be easier to read, but it can be less efficient if you don’t have a good query optimizer.
Nice catch, thanks <@U1VD2FR1U>!

Also for the first query, bad coding practice is used.
The date condition should be in WHERE rather than JOIN and date formats should be provided.
```
WHERE to_date(a.date, 'YYYY-MM-DD') < to_date('2014-06-01', 'YYYY-MM-DD')
```

<https://github.com/zipfian/solns-seattle4/blob/master/assessments/final-assessment/sql_questions.sql>
I believe the second query is wrong. If student applied to the same company twice, he would be double counted. Only counting distinct students is correct.
```
SELECT
    c.id, c.name, COUNT(DISTINCT a.stud_id)
FROM companies c
LEFT OUTER JOIN applications a
ON c.id = a.comp_id
GROUP BY c.id, c.name;
```
